metadata.source: WHO Global Snakebite Initiative, KEMRI Kenya Snake Database
metadata.description: Verified snake species data for East Africa region with medical significance

snakeSpecies.description: Highly venomous snake with neurotoxic venom. Can deliver multiple bites in rapid succession.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, KEMRI Field Studies 2023

snakeSpecies.description: Venomous cobra that can spit venom up to 2 meters. Causes severe tissue damage.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, CDC Venom Research

snakeSpecies.description: Heavy-bodied viper with cytotoxic venom causing severe tissue necrosis.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, KEMRI Clinical Studies

snakeSpecies.description: Small but highly venomous viper. Causes severe bleeding disorders.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, CDC Hemotoxic Venom Studies

snakeSpecies.description: Spitting cobra with cytotoxic venom. Can cause blindness if venom enters eyes.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, KEMRI Ocular Venom Studies

snakeSpecies.description: Small burrowing snake with cytotoxic venom. Unusual fang structure.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, KEMRI Burrowing Snake Studies

snakeSpecies.description: Rear-fanged snake with hemotoxic venom causing severe bleeding.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, CDC Hemotoxic Research

snakeSpecies.description: Rear-fanged snake with hemotoxic venom. Excellent camouflage.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, KEMRI Arboreal Snake Studies

snakeSpecies.description: Arboreal viper with hemotoxic venom. Beautiful but dangerous.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, KEMRI Forest Snake Studies

snakeSpecies.description: Small viper with cytotoxic venom. Generally not life-threatening.
snakeSpecies.source: WHO Snakebite Database, KEMRI Minor Venom Studies

venomTypes.name: Neurotoxic
venomTypes.treatmentNotes: Requires immediate antivenom. Monitor respiratory function. WHO Protocol: Administer polyvalent antivenom within 4 hours.

venomTypes.name: Hemotoxic
venomTypes.treatmentNotes: Monitor coagulation parameters. May require blood products. WHO Protocol: Administer specific antivenom and monitor bleeding.

venomTypes.name: Cytotoxic
venomTypes.treatmentNotes: Local tissue damage. Debridement may be required. WHO Protocol: Wound care, antibiotics, pain management.
